title: Red Sox designate Hanley Ramirez for assignment so they can save $22 million
summary: The Red Sox are parting ways with Hanley Ramirez to make room for Dustin Pedroia on the major league roster.

author: DeltaBravo
title: Madden: Yankees need more pitching if they want to make a World Series run
summary: Ouch. That last one hurts, but if Connie Mack was right when he allegedly said pitching was 75% of baseball, the Yankee starters pale in comparison to the rotations of the Astros and Red Sox, either or both of whom they will have to get past in the postseason, depending on whether they are able to win the AL East outright. The Astros starters presently lead the majors — by a lot — in ERA (2.25), batting average against (.186) and innings per start (6.40) — to the Yankees' 4.13, .229 and 5.43. The Red Sox starters are third in ERA (3.54) and innings per start (5.82)

author: captainunderoos
title: Around the Empire: Yankees news
summary: New York Post | Greg Joyce - The Robinson Cano story will never end. Last week, Mark Teixeira drew everyone's attention when he remarked that the second baseman's suspension didn't surprise him. Now, CC Sabathia responded. “I don't want to get into what Tex said, but I'll just put it like this: I'm not surprised he said that, coming from him,” the big left-hander explained. I suspect this exchange isn't over, but you hate to see former teammates get involved in drama. Can't we all go back to when they palled around at Sabathia's grandiose birthday parties? NorthJersey.com | Pete Caldera - It's hard to believe, but we're getting close to Old-Timer's Day. Yesterday the Yankees revealed their list

author: nanook
title: Big Ten Baseball Tournament: Michigan walked-off by Purdue in second round
summary: Just a little more than 24 hours after a walk-off victory versus No. 6 Iowa, the No. 3 Michigan Wolverines were walked-off by the No. 2 Purdue Boilermakers in the second round of the Big Ten Tournament on Thursday. Purdue's Evan Warden delivered the game-winning single in the ninth inning off of Michigan lefty closer William Tribucher. Purdue got on the board in the bottom of the first inning courtesy of Jacson McGowan's two-out RBI single. In the fourth, Evan Kennedy's run-scoring triple to straightaway center field scored Ben Nisle from first, pushing the Boilermakers' lead to 2-0. Alec Olund brought home Kennedy with an RBI-groundout moments later to extend the lead to 3-0. The Michigan offense

author: rocky.j.mountain
title: Top fantasy baseball free agents by position
summary: With Eric Karabell taking some well-earned time off, I'm back in the waiver wire saddle this week. I'll be offering up a list of players rostered in less than half of ESPN's standard leagues whose play of late merits a potential pickup. Very notably not on the list is Juan Soto of the Washington Nationals, whose ownership has shot up to 66.3 percent after just 10 at-bats. With series against the Miami Marlins and Baltimore Orioles next up for the Nationals, it would not be surprising to see him succeed at the plate for the remainder of May. As for the picks who do qualify for inclusion, I present the following for your consideration: Catcher Francisco Pena, St. Louis Cardinals (0.9 percent):

author: nanook
title: Braves make rotation change for series opener vs. Red Sox
summary: Massachusetts native Sean Newcomb was in line to make a homecoming start for the Atlanta Braves at Fenway Park on Friday night. Instead, he will wait until Saturday as manager Brian Snitker has moved Julio Teheran into the Friday start against the Boston Red Sox and he did it for good reason. Newcomb has thrived when given an extra days' rest.

author: rocky.j.mountain
title: He did what!? Video: LSU reliever Todd Peterson blasts 2-run double in pinch-hit spot
summary: Based off of his first career at-bat, LSU's Todd Peterson may want to step off the mound and into the batter's box more often. With two outs in the top of the 12th inning of Thursday's win-or-go-home game with South Carolina in the Southeastern Conference tournament, the sophomore relief pitcher knocked a two-run double to give the Tigers a 6-3 lead over the Gamecocks. The Tigers would go on to win the game game 6-4.  When asked about the hit after the win, Peterson told the SEC Network he was looking to "go yard" in his first at bat, nothing that "(He) hit bombs in high school." Peterson also picked up the win as pitcher, throwing for five innings giving up four hits, two earned runs and registering

author: DeltaBravo
title: Orioles' Chris Davis responds, says he's 'disappointed' by Hall of Famer Jim Palmer's criticism
summary: In a stern rebuke laying out what his own Hall of Fame eyes tell him, Orioles broadcaster Jim Palmer used his platform on the team's postgame show after Wednesday's loss to the Chicago White Sox to lay out the issues he sees with slumping slugger Chris Davis. Palmer questioned the work that Davis was putting into turning things around, and in the process, challenged the truth of comments made by Davis and hitting coach Scott Coolbaugh about their offseason work together. Davis and Coolbaugh responded with their thoughts Thursday, each providing his own account of what they did and did not do together. The only commonality was that something needs to change, and fast, as situations like what transpired over 12 hours in Chicago on Thursday morning are what make a bad season like the Orioles are enduring far worse.

author: DeltaBravo
title: Still a Phillie, Cesar Hernandez earns skipper's respect as 'epitome of a winning player'
summary: Cesar Hernandez no longer has Freddy Galvis. But the Phillies' second baseman is still here and proving he can do it on his own, too. By Jim Salisbury

author: rocky.j.mountain
title: Ronald Torreyes is the luckiest man on the Yankees
summary: A lot of words have been said and written about Gary Sanchez's string of bad luck to start the 2018 season. While it was extraordinary, everyone knew it wouldn't last. Gary Sanchez is not a .050 hitter, in the same way that Ronald Torreyes is not a .340 hitter. If you just did a double take, join the club. As of this writing Ronald Torreyes is hitting .340/.352/.434 with a 113 wRC+, firmly above league average. Being a bench player is difficult in its own way. Sometimes you'll not play for 4-5 straight days and then be asked to have a competitive at bat against one of the best pitchers on planet Earth. The silver lining is that when you do play, it's because management thinks it's a good match

author: third_watch
title: The uplifting story of how baseball saved Alex Postma and the infuriating story of how it sent him crashing again
summary: This should be an uplifting story about the gift of baseball, the power of acceptance, the way a team and community rallied around a boy. It's also a story of small-town infighting, of a dubious investigation and a governing body struggling to reconcile the letter of the law with its spirit.

author: ipostwhaticareabout
title: MLB trade rumors: Royals to be summer sellers
summary: It's pretty clear the Royals aren't going to contend for a postseason spot this year, and it appears they're going to be summer sellers. According to MLB Insider Jon Heyman, the Royals are "quietly" informing teams that they are open for business, though no trades are immanent. The Royals (16-33) are last in the American League Central with little hope for improvement even though they do have some intriguing trade pieces. “As you know, when a team isn't performing as well as they'd like, it makes sense to be open-minded concerning trade scenarios,” general manager Dayton Moore told Heyman. “But I wouldn't say we are moving quickly on the trade front.” Teams could be intrigued by royals closer

author: captainunderoos
title: Farm Report: David Fletcher, Austin Riley and other notable prospects
summary: David Fletcher and Austin Riley have been feasting at Triple-A, building strong cases for summer promotions. Let's discuss those two, as well as the usual suspects.

author: rocky.j.mountain
title: The Indians are Murphy's Law made manifest
summary: The 2018 Cleveland Indians have been quite something to behold. Even with the inaction of the offseason and the big losses in the bullpen a .500 record seems something short of expectations. They're still in first, but it doesn't feel right. It doesn't seem like they should be such a mediocre team. The bullpen is not as great as it was, a big offensive contributor is gone, but the rotation is better than ever and the offense is loud as hell. And yet still they barely have their head above water. Like Mr. Murphy said, everything that could go wrong has gone utterly sideways. Look, we all knew the bullpen wasn't going to be as good. Maybe the loss of Mickey Callaway was undersold a bit (at least

author: ipostwhaticareabout
title: Will the Best Start in Franchise History Lead to a Record Number of All-Stars for Milwaukee?
summary: Through 50 games, the Milwaukee Brewers are 31-19, which is statistically their best start in franchise history. They lead the NL in several notable categories like team ERA and HRs and if you've watched the Brewers this year, you know it's been primarily a total team effort. But which individuals are making the best case to represent Milwaukee in the Mid-Summer's Classic this July in Washington DC? Does this year's team have a shot at equaling or breaking the organization's high-water mark of four representatives (4 times: 1982, 1983, 2007, 2014)? It will be a challenge, but it is possible. Lead Pipe Lock (Barring Injury) Josh Hader – RP Barring complete collapse or injury, Hader will be an

author: rocky.j.mountain
title: Will Trevor Bauer-Gerrit Cole beef ever die? 'Not going to happen,' says one
summary: Gerrit Cole and Trevor Bauer won't bother to sugarcoat it: They can't stand one another. These two celebrated pitchers, former collegiate teammates at UCLA, still don't talk to one another. They refuse to even speak about one another. They won't even look at one another. Now, they'll have no choice. For the first time in their professional careers, they're scheduled to square off Sunday when the Houston Astros play the Cleveland Indians at Progressive Field. Who knows, maybe when the game ends, they'll exchange pleasantries, complement one another, and finally end this nine-year cold war? Or maybe not. “I would have to say the odds of the earth burning up are better than that,'' Cal State Fullerton

author: captainunderoos
title: Jose Iglesias is turning his season around
summary: It is no secret that shortstop José Iglesias is eligible for free agency at the conclusion of the 2018 season. The Tigers signed the 28-year old to a one-year, $6.275 million deal in the off-season, avoiding arbitration in the process. With the Tigers firmly in rebuilding mode, despite sitting just three games out of first place in the abysmal American League Central, Iglesias is among several players that general manager Al Avila was likely hoping would have a bit of trade value as the deadline approaches in July. That hope appeared to be disintegrating early in the season, as Iglesias got off to a nightmarish 2-for-35 start in his first 10 games. Ever since the Tigers' suffered a four-game

author: rocky.j.mountain
title: Angels push back Otani's next outing as starting pitcher
summary: TORONTO (AP) — The Los Angeles Angels are pushing back Shohei Otani's next outing as a starting pitcher to manage the workload of the two-way rookie. Angels manager Mike Scioscia made the announcement Thursday. Otani is 4-1 with a 3.35 ERA in seven starts. He had been scheduled to pitch against fellow Japanese right-hander Masahiro Tanaka at Yankee Stadium on Sunday. Scioscia said Otani would be available to hit against Tanaka. The Angels haven't set a date for Otani's next outing. Otani last pitched May 20 against Tampa Bay, winning his second straight decision and giving up two runs and six hits in a season-high 7 2-3 innings. His 110 pitches were also a season-high. Otani has started at designated

author: rocky.j.mountain
title: A Yankees fan caught a Neil Walker home run with a dramatic fall over a railing
summary: A Yankees fan fell over a railing to make a dramatic and spectacular catch.

author: captainunderoos
title: Mets manager benches Jose Reyes and tries to lift his spirits
summary: After Jose Reyes made two errors at third base on Tuesday, Mets manager Mickey Callaway went with Luis Guillorme in Frazier's spot on Wednesday. Callaway said he spoke to Reyes following Tuesday's game, when one of his miscues led to a pair of unearned runs against Zack Wheeler. “No matter the age or how long you've been playing, people need words of encouragement,'' Callaway said before the Mets' 2-1 loss to the Marlins Wednesday night at Citi Field. “We're trying to pick up everybody every day, trying to help them be better each day. He definitely needs it.” Guillorme went 0-for-4 with two strikeouts. Callaway said he expects to give Amed Rosario a day off “in the next couple of days. The Mets

author: nanook
title: The only downside of the Braves' hot start
summary: The Braves have been the talk of the league through the first two months of the season. National writers are beginning to take notice. And while some expected the club to take a step forward with an influx of young talent, no one thought Atlanta would be near the top of the National League on May 24th. The Braves have indeed been very good as we approach Memorial Day. They're among the league leaders (if not the leaders) in every offensive category. The pitching has been good enough thanks to steps taken forward by a handful of young starters. The defense has improved. Base running has improved. Brian Snitker hasn't made nearly as many head-scratching decisions as in years past. It's been far
